summary_points: 1. Joseph V. Taranto retired as Chair of Everest Group, Ltd.'s Board of Directors, effective May 2025, and John Graf was nominated to succeed him.
2.  Joseph V. Taranto served as Everest's Board Chair since 1994 and as CEO from 1994 to 2013.
3. John Graf, nominated to succeed Mr. Taranto, has been an independent board member since 2016 and is the non-Executive Vice Chairman of Global Atlantic Financial Group.
1. On March 23, 2025, Steven J. Moskowitz was terminated as President and CEO of Crown Castle Inc., with Daniel K. Schlanger appointed as Interim President and CEO.

2. Daniel K. Schlanger received a $100,000 monthly stipend, $4,125,000 in 2025 RSUs, $4,100,000 in promotion RSUs, and $1,000,000 in transformation RSUs as part of his appointment as Interim President and CEO, effective March 23, 2025.
3. The sale of Crown Castle's Fiber business is expected to close in the first half of 2026.
1. Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. (CECONY) entered into a new $500 million 364-day revolving credit agreement on March 24, 2025, replacing an expired agreement.

2.  The new credit agreement's covenants restrict CECONY's consolidated debt to consolidated total capital ratio from exceeding 0.65 to 1 and limit liens on assets to 10% of consolidated net tangible assets.
3.  A change of control at CECONY or its parent company, Consolidated Edison, Inc., could trigger immediate repayment of the $500 million loan.
1. On March 24, 2025, Cintas Corporation terminated discussions with UniFirst Corporation regarding a proposed cash acquisition of UniFirst for $275.00 per share.
2.  Cintas's proposed acquisition of UniFirst represented a 46% premium over UniFirst's ninety-day average closing price as of January 6, 2025.
3. Cintas stated it will continue to pursue its existing growth strategy, including mergers and acquisitions and technology investments.
1. Lowe's net sales decreased by 3.1% year-over-year to $83.7 billion in fiscal year 2024.
2.  Lowe's projects $2.5 billion in capital expenditures for fiscal year 2025.
3. Lowe's has $965 million in non-cancellable commitments scheduled for payment in fiscal year 2025.

1.  At the March 20, 2025, annual shareholder meeting, a shareholder proposal requesting a report on climate risks to retirement plan beneficiaries failed to pass, receiving only 87,209,412 votes in favor versus 1,128,514,198 against.

2.  All proposed directors were elected at the March 20, 2025, shareholder meeting, with Robert A. Iger receiving the highest number of "for" votes (1,213,662,424) and Derica W. Rice receiving the lowest (1,182,301,425).
3. The appointment of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as independent registered public accountants for fiscal year 2025 was ratified by shareholders, with 1,374,322,498 votes in favor.

1. On March 24, 2025, Advanced Micro Devices Inc. closed a public offering of $1.5 billion in senior notes, consisting of $875 million in 4.212% notes due 2026 and $625 million in 4.319% notes due 2028.
2.  Also on March 24, 2025, the company issued $950 million in unsecured commercial paper under a previously disclosed program.

3.  The indenture governing the senior notes includes covenants limiting the company's ability to create liens on certain assets, enter into sale and leaseback transactions, and undergo certain mergers or asset sales; these covenants are subject to exceptions.

1. News Corp repurchased approximately US$651,674,151.65 worth of Class A and Class B shares as of March 21, 2025, under a stock repurchase program authorized to acquire up to US$1 billion in aggregate.
2. On March 21, 2025,  21,311,148 Class A shares and 10,516,036 Class B shares were repurchased at a highest price of US$30.69 and US$35.25 respectively.
3. News Corp intends to continue repurchasing its Class A and Class B common stock from time to time, subject to market conditions and other factors.

1. EQT Corporation extended the expiration date of its exchange offers and consent solicitations from March 24, 2025, to March 28, 2025, to exchange outstanding notes issued by its subsidiary EQM for new notes and cash.

2. As of March 7, 2025, approximately 99.2% of EQM's 7.500% Senior Notes due 2027 were validly tendered, but significantly lower percentages were tendered for other note series, with the lowest being 38.1% for the 5.500% Senior Notes due 2028.

3. EQT waived the condition requiring sufficient consents to amend the indentures governing all outstanding EQM notes; however,  the settlement date is expected to be April 2, 2025,  and  the New Notes have not been registered under the Securities Act of 1933, requiring an exemption for sale in the United States.
